My aunt lived in that area, and we were taken there daily. I can remember her telling me I was special and that I would be a star someday. That I had to do everything she said. Listen, practice.
My father was supposed to be watching my sister and me, but he would take us there and leave us with her. For part of that time we stayed with my aunt until we could get our own place. My father was supposed to be looking for work, but he would take off with my blood uncles every day, so it got to be that I never saw either parent for long periods of time. That would change on occasion when my father would take me with him to bars while he drank or played in a band or both. I would be at the bar with one of his girlfriends. It seemed perfectly natural to me.
My aunt began to sexually abuse me the first night. It continued the entire time we were there. Months. I didn't know until years later that my sister was locked in a closet while this went on.
Eventually we got a place of our own and the abuse stopped.
A few months later my cousins came to live with us and the sexual abuse started again. Just different people. It ended a few months later when they were caught. They had us tied up. The cords were tight. Not really cords at all, cloths line. My sister and I were tied back to back. My cousins, a sister and brother had already molested us for over an hour. I cannot recall where my mother was during that period of my life. She was gone a lot. I think she was working because he didn't work. That's all I know.

There is a war. At home. If only someone knew? THESE ARE THE DOCUMENTS USED IN MY COURT CASE. 

MY other Facebook was shutdown after family court.

These documents of screenshots of my other Facebook that no longer exists are what was used to hand my kids to monsters. Itâ€™s pathetically unjustified. 

My Facebook is the biggest middle finger to my ex & the system. 

I can gage my exâ€™s stalking, rage, anger & find out all his moves from my new Facebook. I communicate through my social media. Itâ€™s the best thing I ever did. Now I have a new Facebook & it is the only place I communicate with my ex. I have control here. The only place you have control is their anger. Go towards the places you have control. It should be illegal for them to use this, but they will & I donâ€™t care because Iâ€™m an American woman. 

I am gagged from even talking about domestic violence & family court corruption. Itâ€™s illegal for me to post pictures of my kids. So what? Let them make it illegal. Iâ€™m gunna show up & do what I want because this is the land of the free. Stop being scared stop telling me how to be. Thatâ€™s rude. 

A judge refused to look at a single picture, video or medical records of my kids abuse. Years of documentation thrown out the window so I can be punished for nothing. Wake up. Turn your lights on. 

Family court is a joke. My gag order is completely unconstitutional & corrupt. 

Stop telling me what to post & not to post. I have already been there & done that. Theyâ€™re gunna use if you sneeze against you. Stop giving into the excuse that I need to not show up so I wonâ€™t â€œget in troubleâ€ so stupid. They already took my kids. I donâ€™t have anything to lose.

Remember this cover and the Me Too movement? It was 2017 and the "silence breakers" were Time's Person of the Year.

Time wrote: "These silence breakers have started a revolution of refusal, gathering strength by the day, and in the past two months alone, their collective anger has spurred immediate and shocking results: nearly every day."

WHERE ARE THEY NOW? 

Mass rape on October 7th, mass rape of the hostages. Their silence is louder than any sound. 

If you know a Me Too pioneer or a silent celebrity, implore them to speak out. It is never too late.

What does it really mean when you invite someone back to your place? 
It means that you invite them back to your place. Nothing More. 
Saying yes to go to someone's place doesn't equal or even imply consent to any sexual activity. 
It also doesn't mean anyone owes anyone anything.

DESCRIPTION:
Listen to Anna, a survivor of teen dating violence. Sheâ€™s courageously telling us what we need to hear, not only during Teen Dating Awareness Month #TDVAM, as @thefeministparent explains in her latest reel (check it out).

As a freshman, Anna was â€œinstantly hookedâ€ by a varsity athlete who made her feel greatâ€”until he didnâ€™t. Read her @womensmediacenter story via our highlights or linktree.

Anna wants people to learn the warning signs of teen dating and how to get help. She recommends @sashclubs â€œTeen Dating Violenceâ€ Power Topic presentation, via our Power Topics highlight or linktree.

Like many survivors of abuse by male athletes, she found it pointless to report because the school ignored victims. If Annaâ€™s school had supported reporting students, she could have avoided years of trauma. Schools must create a safe environment for all students, take reports compassionately, and act quickly to stop the harassment. Too often schools donâ€™t--so students are denied their right to an education free from sexual harassment as guaranteed by Title IX, a federal civil rights law.

Use @ssaisorg toolkits (in our highlights) to ensure your school is taking the required steps to protect students.

#teendatingviolence #tdvam
#sexdiscrimination #titleix #sexualharassment #studentclub #teen #parenting #rapevictim #rapeculture #believe #believesurvivors #sexualassault #students #counseling #teenproblems #lgbtqstudents #metook12 #sashclub #ssais

âœ¨ Setting and respecting boundaries is vital in any relationship so that all partners feel safe communicating their needs without fear of retaliation. Healthy relationships involve comfortable dialogues around wants, goals, fears, and limits, with the understanding that everyone's expressed boundaries will be honored. Boundaries can come in many different forms: 

ğŸ§  Emotional: Trust and comfort are essential in a healthy relationship that partners build over time by demonstrating reliability.

âœ‹ Physical: Partners know how far the other wants to go based on open communication. Your boundaries should always reflect how ready you feel personally.

ğŸ’» Digital: You and your partner should feel able to discuss your needs and wants. Remember: changes to the terms should be made together with respect.

ğŸ—¯ï¸ Conflict: Conflict is normal, but your arguments shouldnâ€™t turn into personal attacks. If you canâ€™t express yourself without fear of retaliation, you may be experiencing abuse.

Follow @loveisrespectofficial and visit â¡ï¸ https://www.loveisrespect.org/everyone-deserves-a-healthy-relationship/how-to-set-boundaries/ for more information on setting boundaries for a healthy relationship.
#metoo #domesticviolence #sexualassault #believesurvivors #stopviolenceagainstwomen

Trigger warning - unpopular opinion...

As a psychologist, wellness coach, and human being, I often feel like the world/society is moving in the exact opposite direction than what I'm doing and what my worldview is.

From the #metoo movement, to #democracy, from #healthcare in general to #conspiracytheory and so many more topics... I have a fundamentalky different opinion than the overall concesus seems to be.

I feel the world/society has gotten ridiculous! We've gone absolutely mad as a species. And yes, that is my professional opinion.

I see so many people being confused about their basic identity, people being overly sensitive and expecting everyone around them to take their specific preferences and possible triggers into account (which, by the way are different for each individual AND not the world's responsibility), doctors having no clue about actual health care, people being offered the option to get euthanized simply because main stream therapists don't have the holistic knowledge and experience to treat people properly. We're being co-erced and gaslit into taking experimental shots, with no liability of the manufacturers. We're being led to believe that there is a climate crisis that can be stopped by cutting off our food supply (farmers) and replace it with artifial meat and such, while formula 1 continues.

I mean, come on! 

Your health, your triggers, your decisions, healing from trauma, finding the right therapists and doctors for YOU, creating safety... is YOUR responsibility. No one else's. It's time to take your power back!! Because the world  needs you happy, healthy, and thriving, not constantly in survival mode from trying to fit into a profoundly sick society. The world needs your contribution, not your whining. The world needs you to shine bright, so everything that is lurking in the shadows can come to the surface and dissipate.

I'll keep empowering my clients as much as I can. Because I believe that is the road to a better world. Inspiring people to take the reigns of their lives and make heartfelt decisions that are aligned with their true being.

#holisticwellnesscoaching #healing #trauma #triggers #unpopularopinion #wellnessinmind

DESCRIPTION:
I firmly believe that challenges are opportunities in disguise, presenting us with valuable lessons and insights to grow from. Instead of dwelling on the unfairness of a situation, I choose to channel my energy into understanding how I can emerge stronger and wiser. Shifting oneâ€™s perspective from victimhood to empowerment can be transformative. Every setback becomes a stepping stone, propelling us forward on our journey. Despite the trials Iâ€™ve faced, I refuse to be defined by them; rather, I am defined by my resilience and determination to overcome. Itâ€™s this mindset that has enabled me to navigate lifeâ€™s tumultuous waters and emerge triumphant, time and time again.

Just sharing another shot from Saturday night because itâ€™s all still sinking in. And I should share the hell out of the pics. It was a huge undertaking, doing my own show. Today, in a cafe, I had a lovely lady stop me and tell me she was there, and throughly enjoyed it! How bizarre is that.

I like this one because @norbertdrebin74 and I look a little more thoughtful, more serious. Because of course there were laughs, but it was also an intense show, and very personal. I had to be very vulnerable. We both did.

Iâ€™ve been exhausted this week. But thatâ€™s understandable. I was out of my comfort zone. But Iâ€™m so glad I did it.

Teen dating violence takes many forms including psychological aggression: verbal or non-verbal communication to emotionally harm or control another person. It can also include repeated, unwanted attention or contact (like intrusively checking emails and texts) that causes fear or concern for oneâ€™s own safety. The many warning signs are included in our Teen Dating Violence Power Topic (via highlights). It offers a fast-moving video â€œDating Abuse: Toolkit for Talking to Teensâ€ with scenarios for people of all genders created by @jewishwomenintl. Thanks for collaborating, CEO 
@meredith_jacobs.

Trying to make all the changes at once.

Tarana Burke, founder of the 2006 #MeToo movement is helping women find their voice, get their power back, and speak out regarding sexual violence and assault. Burke is an activist for racial, economic and gender equality. To add, Burke organizes workshops across the country to help improve policies at places of worship, work, and schools that focuses on helping victims not blame themselves for sexual violence. If you or someone else is a victim of sexual assault and need help gaining your voice and power back and need great resources to get you started, please visit https://metoomvmt.org/

Touch is something that comes up whenever we talk about intimacy. How we view touch as men is often skewed by homophobia and patriarchal ideas of sexualisation and domination. 

So many societies around the world have a different relationship with masculine intimacy, not to say that they are perfect, but from a western perspective, we are lacking.

Read the full article here - https://menagainstpatriarchy.co.uk/

What are your thought on male touch? How can we regain our sense of love and appreciation in platonic, non sexual ways?

â€œBut the idea of parental alienation has come under scrutiny in recent years, as women and domestic violence experts have increasingly pointed out that claims of parental alienation often involve cases that stem from domestic abuse resulting in the allegedly abused parent being naturally resistant to allowing the abusive ex-partner to continue parenting the child. Divorced women are claiming they are encouraged by attorneys not to mention domestic violence in their court proceedings for fear of a claim of parental alienation being used against them in custody proceedings.

Studies have shown that when a claim of parental alienation is made, courts increasingly side with the alienated party and often reverse custody orders, returning children to an abusive parent. A 2023 report to the United Nations, labeled parental alienation a â€œpseudo-conceptâ€ that endangers the lives of women and children. The idea of parental alienation as a psychological disorder has also come under heavy scrutiny by other psychologists.â€

DESCRIPTION:
My name is #PatriciaDouglas

"The Patricia Douglas case is probably the biggest, best-suppressed scandal in Hollywood history." Vanity Fair.

Take a look at the story that inspired the show and the character of #GirlNextDoor played by @yorkshirewade

Trigger Warning: Themes of sexual assault.

On the evening of May 5, 1937, a 20-year-old Patricia Douglas was brought to work at an MGM party, under the guise of a casting call, with more than 120 other young women.

Herded into a large banquet hall, they were ordered to sit at tables and wait. Studio bosses, assorted MGM bigwigs, male stars, and almost 300 revved-up conventioneers appeared.

Given that they had been promised a stag affair, the salesmenâ€™s lust-at-first-sight response to a bevy of young, over-made-up beauties makes sad and terrible sense. Delegates mistook the girls for party favors and treated them accordingly; without telephones or transportation, the young women had no means of escape. Tricked into attendance, then trapped into service, they were left to fend for themselves.

Patricia Douglas was one of the first people to come forward after experiencing sexual assault in the film industry, leading to a massive scandal that MGM minimized by a smear campaign. In what was a legal first Patricia Douglas was the first female plaintiff to make rape a federal case based on her civil rights.

Thirty something Vanessa Wye is working a dead end job as a hotel concierge. Dealing with the loss of her father and the slow decline of her once bright academic future, she has sunk into a cycle of alcohol and drugs, just barely managing to keep her head above water. 

At the height of #MeToo, her high school teacher, Jacob Strane, is accused of sexually abusing several girls. This brings back long buried memories of Vanessaâ€™s own troubled relationship with Strane. 
.
ğ™ğ™šğ™«ğ™ğ™šğ™¬:
ğŸ¥€ The two timelines - one by a jaded adult Vanessa and the other by the optimistic 15 year old who has a crush on 42 year old English teacher - make for a brilliant and poignant contrast.

ğŸ¥€ I loved Vanessaâ€™s character progression from a flirty teen to an abused, brainwashed young woman and then to an adult whose life is shaped (and destroyed) by that abuse. I found adult Vanessaâ€™s weird obsessive love/hate relationship with Strane very interesting.

ğŸ¥€ Strane is obviously despicable and manipulative, but looking at him from Vanessaâ€™s POV still manages to muddy the lens you view him through. This is a testament to how well Vanessa is written. 

ğŸ¥€ I wonâ€™t lie. This book was deeply disturbing and difficult to read.

.

#FromTheArchive | It was January 2019, the time around which an international movement called #MeToo was gaining prominence in India. #MeToo was a socÂ­ial-media-driven campaign that started in 2017, when women across the globe started speaking up against sexual harassment, inspÂ­iÂ­red by American activist and rape survivor TarÂ­ana Burke. In India, #MeToo began with allÂ­eÂ­gations by and against Bollywood celebritÂ­ies, and gathered steam on social media. As a result, small towns and rural India remained blissfully unaware.

But for many women, it is not easy to speak up, especially in rural areas where conservative and regressive mores automatically tend to put the blame on women who speak up.

Mayank Jain Parichha writes.

Note: Ahead of Womenâ€™s Day, Outlook looks back at its archive stories on women who are unapologetic about who they are.

Even in healthy relationships without abuse, communication can be difficult and we may escalate conflict by not using the best communication skills. When someone elseâ€™s actions evoke an upsetting emotional response within us, how can we communicate this?

A common communication error is when we use an accusatory or blame statement. In these statements, we say something such as, â€œYou donâ€™t care about me,â€ or â€œYouâ€™re mad at me right now.â€ When we say these statements, we are telling the other person what their intentions or feelings are, when in reality, what we are trying to communicate is what emotions come up for us when something happens.

Try the â€œI feelâ€¦ when youâ€¦ I wishâ€¦ becauseâ€ sentence structure. By using this structure, we address our feelings and donâ€™t make the other person responsible for them. We also explain what about it evoked this emotional response and how you both can navigate the issue in the future.

Remember: emotions just are. No one is to blame for them, not ourselves nor our partner. While we may not have full control over what emotions we experience, we have control over how we respond to them. Additionally, please keep in mind that this communication strategy does not apply in abusive relationships. If you feel like your relationship is abusive, please contact the Domestic Violence Hotline at:

800-799-7233

DESCRIPTION:
Love bombing is a manipulation tactic for control, used in abusive relationships and by those with insecure attachment seeking power. It is when, primarily at the beginning of a relationship, your partner â€œbombsâ€ you with extreme displays of affection and attention in order to manipulate you.

We often hear about the â€œhoneymoon phaseâ€ in relationships where, typically at the beginning of the relationship, partners are more affectionate and give more focus to the relationship than normal. How do we know the difference? 

In love bombing, itâ€™s a cycle. They start by showering you with affection, but quickly switch to denying you love and attention as a way to manipulate you into doing things to get that attention back. In the honeymoon phase, you will begin to display more normal levels of attention and affection slowly and gradually overtime as the newness of the relationship wears off. Love and affection is not withheld in an attempt to receive something in return.

Â«Â Le consentementÂ Â» de Vanessa Springora @vanessa.springora 

Quel courage il a fallu Ã  lâ€™autrice pour lâ€™Ã©crire. Avec quel brio elle raconte cette emprise que peut avoir un adulte sur un enfant de 14, 15 puis 16 ans.

On est dans sa peau, sa peau dâ€™enfant regardÃ©e et flattÃ©e, qui a si soif dâ€™amour et dâ€™aventure, quâ€™elle hurlerait Ã©videmment son consentement (si on le lui demandait).

Mais cela sâ€™appelle de la pÃ©dophilie.

Et notre rÃ´le dâ€™adulte câ€™est aussi de protÃ©ger les enfants dâ€™eux mÃªmes et de leurs dÃ©sirs.

Car cette emprise basÃ©e sur le dÃ©sÃ©quilibre ne peut glisser que vers la cruautÃ©, la dÃ©gradation, lâ€™enfermement, lâ€™abus. Un enfant et un adulte ne jouent pas avec les mÃªmes rÃ¨gles, les actes et les mots nâ€™ont pas les mÃªmes sens pour eux. Il nâ€™y a quâ€™avec son regard dâ€™adulte que lâ€™enfant pourra comprendre plus tard ce qui sâ€™est jouÃ©.

Horreur de constater que cela est vÃ©cu au grand jour, que le prÃ©dateur (qui est Ã©crivain) sâ€™en vante dans son Å“uvre ou sur des plateaux tv. Et personne ne dit rien, ne fait rien.

Une mÃ¨re qui laisse faire, un pÃ¨re absent, des amis de la mÃ¨re qui rÃ©agissent parfois bien que trÃ¨s mollement, une Ã©poque permissiveâ€¦ Voici la petite V. jetÃ©e en pÃ¢ture, qui a la force de piÃ©ger lâ€™agresseur Ã  son propre piÃ¨ge : en lâ€™enfermant dans un livre!! 

Jâ€™espÃ¨re que lâ€™autrice arrive Ã  ressentir aujourdâ€™hui sa force et sa victoire. Je les ressens tellement en refermant ce livre.

PS : Je nâ€™ai pas encore vu le film tirÃ© de ce livre, mais la sÃ©rie Â«Â icon of french cinemaÂ Â» de Judith GodrÃ¨che @judithgodreche1 qui aborde entre autre le mÃªme thÃ¨me est canon!! Je vous la conseille vivement.

La ceremonia, que se celebra en el Teatro Olympia de ParÃ­s, estÃ¡ condicionada por las denuncias de las actrices Judith GodrÃ¨che e Isild Le Besco contra los directores BenoÃ®t Jacquot y Jacques Doillon.
El cine francÃ©s celebra este viernes su gala anual, los premios CÃ©sar, atormentado nuevamente por denuncias de violencia sexual, esta vez de actrices que eran menores cuando fueron supuestamente vÃ­ctimas de directores abusivos. La tempestad del movimiento #MeToo no ha amainado en Francia, sino todo lo contrario, y la nueva oleada de acusaciones es liderada por la actriz Judith GodrÃ¨che (51 aÃ±os), acompaÃ±ada en un segundo plano por Isild Le Besco (41). Ambas acusan a los cineastas BenoÃ®t Jacquot y Jacques Doillon de haber ejercido un autÃ©ntico â€œdominioâ€ psicolÃ³gico sobre ellas hace dÃ©cadas, cuando empezaban en el mundo del cine.

In honour of Black History Month, Black Excellence: A Heritage to Celebrate; a Future to Build, SSAIC would like to recognize Mikki Kendall. 

Mikki Kendall is the author of a New York Times bestseller, Hood Feminism: Notes from the Women That a Movement Forgot, as well as many liberating and profound essays published in platforms such as TIME, the New York Times, The Guardian, the Washington Post, Vogue, and many others. 

Kendall has worn many hats in the span of her career but her focus throughout has surrounded topics of feminism, race, diversity and representation. 

In her book, Hood Feminism, Kendal expresses her activism for women of colour by criticizing the feminist movement for being largely "the province of the privileged" and ignoring problems that disproportionately impact communities of color, including poverty, housing, medical care, and racism. 

The book stands as an essential tool for particularly white women to utilize. This book allow's women of privilege a lens into understanding the impacts of intersectionality and its effects. Kendall draws on her own experiences of hunger, violence, and hypersexualization, to shine a light on a movement that chronically fails to address the needs of all but a few women. 

Kendall's book is a fierce and necessary step towards acknowledging intersectionality and abolishing the line between women experiencing it and those that are privileged enough no to, within a movement essential to all. 

To learn more about Mikki Kendal and her works, check out her website at https://mikkikendall.com/ or scroll through her Instagram @karnythia.

It may be the end of #TeenDatingViolenceAwarenessMonth, but that doesnâ€™t mean that the conversation has to end here. We wanted to take the time today to provide some support to parents.

A common barrier for teens when it comes to reporting dating or sexual violence is that they donâ€™t feel like they have a safe adult to disclose to. They may fear that their parents may get too sad hearing what theyâ€™ve been through, or may even get angry at them, blame them, or otherwise become aggressive. The first step to prevent further harm is to create a safe space for disclosure.

Parents, even if your child has never shared any experiences like these with you, itâ€™s important that you are mindful of how you interact with them and these topics in different contexts. Your teen will often think back to your demeanor in other contexts to determine whether or not you are a safe person to disclose to.

Swipe to learn some ways to foster a relationship with your child that demonstrates that you are a safe adult to disclose to before it happens.

DESCRIPTION:
We hope to see you for an engaging and inspiring morning at the Betty Griffin Center's First Annual Breakfast on Monday, March 4th, at The Plantation at Ponte Vedra Beach Clubhouse, 220 Plantation Circle.

We'll be hearing from St. Johns County Sheriff Rob Hardwick and survivors and advocates Kristin Paul and Madison Schemitz.

Doors open at 7:00 a.m., with the program starting promptly at 7:30 a.m. Tickets are $75 and may be purchased at https://bit.ly/BGC1stAnnualBreakfast.

Your attendance isn't just about breakfast; it's a testament to your commitment to supporting survivors on their journey to healing and empowerment. Your participation will directly contribute to funding crucial services, such as emergency shelter, counseling, legal support, and preventive education programs

The Betty Griffin Center offers vital emergency and support services, empowering individuals and their families to reclaim their lives with courage and resilience..

For sponsorship opportunities or inquiries, please contact Kenlie Kubart at kenliek@bettygriffincenter.org or (904) 808-8544 x 207.

The PTSD may be telling you that you can do it alone - either to stay with the abuser - or leave without support - LIE.

You need a step-by-step plan to leave.  Comment STEP and I'll send you my comprehensive "12 Steps to Safety".

.
.
.
Acrylic Self Portrait
~2010-2014 During Highschool
.
.
My art new my secrets before i was able to process how bad things had been. Art pulling from my subconscious, expressing and processing before my cognitive awareness new the severity of what there was to process.
.
.
.
TW: deeper details into my experience
.
.
Might delete these details later. i am worried how they could be interpreted by predetors. 
.
.

Ive expereinced child sexual abuse from a sibiling from as early as i can remeber till about 10years old. It isnt always obvious.it isnt always an adult. It isnt always a man. It was just normal, it was my life.  I was again then assaulted by my boyfriend at the time around 12years old. I was then coerced and pressured by my boyfriend at the time around 14 years old.  I was then persued and emotionally manipualted into sexual dynamic by a 23 year old man over the internet at 15 years old.  I was then raped by an lgbt+ peer at 16 years old, i didnt  cognitivly realise i had been raped till a year later. It was my normal, it was my life. I was persued by and had a relationship with a 26 year old man at 17. I was raped by an lgbt+  peer in my early 20s (between 19-22). I dont remeber my age at the time as i was also navigating an emotionally and mentally abusive relationship.
.
.
.
I am not ONLY what has happened to me, this is not ALL that has happened to me. But it is a lot, and it has shaped me. Im glad im safe now, im glad ive done the work to discern safe connection. 
.
.
My story is unfortuntly common. 
.
.

DESCRIPTION:
In honor of #TeenDatingViolenceAwarenessMonth weâ€™re answering real questions from real teens who have attended PAVE/Survivors.org presentations.

Todayâ€™s Question ğŸ’­
Is virginity a construct? A personally defined construct?

Virginity is defined as the state of being where one has never had sexual intercourse. The short answer is, yes, virginity is a social construct. Historically, it has been used to shame others, primarily women, and define their worth as a result of their sexual activity. However, not everyone views the concept this way.

Whether or not you choose to personally use the term virginity is completely up to you, making it a self-defined concept. Keep in mind that we should never impose this on others. For those who do choose to use the concept of virginity for themselves, they may experience additional distress if they have been sexually assaulted. This is one reason why it is very important that we understand that sex and sexual assault are not the same thing. If you do use the concept of virginity for yourself, being sexually assaulted does not mean you have lost your virginity. Sexual assault is an act of violence, not sexual intercourse.

The mothers of the United States, hereby submit this Demand for Order to Show Cause. This demand is made in pursuit of judicial intervention to address and amend the significant systemic failings within the U.S. family court systemâ€”failings that have detrimentally affected the lives and well-being of children and families nationwide. Central to our demand is the call for comprehensive reforms that align the operations of the family court system with its fundamental commitments to fairness, equity, and the paramountcy of childrenâ€™s best interests.

Through this demand, we call upon the United States of America, the Respondent, to demonstrate cause why it has not undertaken necessary and urgent reforms within the family court system to eliminate procedural inefficiencies, biases, and a lack of transparency that undermine the justice and equity these courts are entrusted to deliver. #familycourt #childrensrights #usa #humanrightswatch #womensrightsarehumanrightsâœŠ #metoofamilycourt #protectivemothersrevolution #usconstitution #uscongress #unitedstates #shadowpandemic #domesticviolenceawarenessmonthğŸ’œ #timesup

DESCRIPTION:
Today, letâ€™s shed light on a grave issue that affects millions of lives worldwide: Human Trafficking. As we observe National Human Trafficking Awareness Day, itâ€™s crucial to educate ourselves about this heinous crime and work together to combat it. 

Signs to watch for:

ğŸ’œ Physical Manifestations: Look out for signs of physical abuse, malnourishment, extreme fatigue, or untreated medical conditions.
 ğŸ’œ Absence of Autonomy: Individuals may have limited or no access to personal identification documents, money, or personal belongings, indicating a lack of control over their own lives.
 ğŸ’œ Communication Restrictions: Victims may be prohibited from speaking for themselves or have limited interaction with others. Their communication may be closely monitored or controlled.
 ğŸ’œ Unconventional Work Situations: Pay attention to individuals who work excessively long hours, reside at their workplace, or display signs of indebtedness to their employer.
ğŸ’œ Behavioural Clues: Victims may exhibit fearful, anxious, depressed, submissive, tense, or nervous/paranoid behavior. They may also avoid making eye contact.
ğŸ’œ Inconsistencies in Narratives: Be cautious of individuals who struggle to clarify their current living arrangements or provide inconsistent explanations about how they ended up in their present circumstances.
 ğŸ’œ Lack of Familiarity with Location or Date: Victims may not know the city they are in, their place of residence, or even the current date.
ğŸ’œ Suspicious Financial Practices: Pay attention if someone else controls their finances or if they possess unexplained significant debts.

DESCRIPTION:
My name is #PatriciaDouglas

"The Patricia Douglas case is probably the biggest, best-suppressed scandal in Hollywood history." Vanity Fair.

Take a look at the story that inspired the show and the character of #GirlNextDoor played by @yorkshirewade 

Trigger Warning: Themes of sexual assault.

On the evening of May 5, 1937, a 20-year-old Patricia Douglas was brought to work at an MGM party, under the guise of a casting call, with more than 120 other young women. 

Herded into a large banquet hall, they were ordered to sit at tables and wait. Studio bosses, assorted MGM bigwigs, male stars, and almost 300 revved-up conventioneers appeared. 

Given that they had been promised a stag affair, the salesmenâ€™s lust-at-first-sight response to a bevy of young, over-made-up beauties makes sad and terrible sense. Delegates mistook the girls for party favors and treated them accordingly; without telephones or transportation, the young women had no means of escape. Tricked into attendance, then trapped into service, they were left to fend for themselves.

Patricia Douglas was one of the first people to come forward after experiencing sexual assault in the film industry, leading to a massive scandal that MGM minimized by a smear campaign. In what was a legal first Patricia Douglas was the first female plaintiff to make rape a federal case based on her civil rights.

DESCRIPTION:
Marie Laura Laliberte

Age 47

Marie Laliberte was 47 when she went missing on New Year's Day in 1997 in Vancouver, B.C. She grew up in Beauval, Saskatchewan. She travelled between Edmonton, Alberta, and Vancouver, and her resource worker at the time reported that she was engaging in a high-risk lifestyle in East Vancouver. She wasn't reported missing until March 8th, 2002 due to the fact that she didn't keep in touch with her family often, and was described to tend towards anti-social behavior. 

More info on link in bio

If you have any information please contact CrimeStoppers @1-800-222-8477(TIPS)

DESCRIPTION:
Marie Lynn Lasas

Age 19

Marie Lynn Lasas was 19 years old and a mother of two children when she went missing. She was walking home on September 21st, 2006, from a friend's place that night. She was reported to have made a stop at her uncle's and then continued on her way home. After that, she disappeared. Nine months later, her body was found behind an abandoned house on the west side of the city where she lived. Police are no longer actively investigating Lasas' death, but the file is still open.

If you have any information please contact CrimeStoppers @1-800-222-8477(TIPS)

In honor of #TeenDatingViolenceAwarenessMonth weâ€™re answering real questions from real teens who have attended PAVE/Survivors.org presentations.

Todayâ€™s Question ğŸ’­
If consent is given for something specific, but something else happens under that â€œpermission,â€ what should you do in the moment?

One of our pillars of consent is the concept that consent is ongoing throughout the entire interaction, such as before engaging in a different sexual act, and consenting to one specific thing does not mean you consent to another.

When it comes to responding in the moment, there is no â€œshould.â€ Our bodies are hardwired to respond to fear, and we generally have little to no control over how our body chooses to respond. No matter what you do in the moment, itâ€™s not your fault.
If something happens to you, or has happened to you that you did not consent to, and you would like support from PAVE, please reach out to our Director of Survivor Support:
(survivorsupport@pavingtheway.net)
or check out survivors.org for information and resources.

Impossible de convaincre tout le monde sur la vÃ©racitÃ© de votre parole, inutile de gaspiller votre Ã©nergie en tentant en vain de convaincre ces personnes. Inutile de vous dÃ©fendre dans le vide, ou de chercher Ã  prouver que vous ne mentez pas, que vous avez raison.

âœ¨Unbound - Tarana Burkeâœ¨ 

ğŸ“š one sentence summary
Memoir of the #MeToo Founder #TaranaBurke .

âœ¨Favorite Quoteâœ¨
â€â€¦and I wondered how that body that holds so much pain could also hold so much joy.â€ Tarana about Maya Angelou

I donâ€™t know what I expected but I didnâ€™t expect THIS. Wow. My heart was shattering into million pieces reading about her experiences and the experiences of the other million girls and women she encountered. She deserves all the recognition and respect for all the work she has done and is still doing to this day.

This book gave me a deeper understanding about the creation of the #MeTooMovement and how it all started and why.
Originally it was meant to empower Black and Brown Girls and to encourage them to share their stories and connect with others who endured the same trauma. 
To this day Black women are at a higher risk of sexual assault, as nearly 1 in 5 BW are survivors of rape (www.nbwji.com) 

The topics are heavy but it needs to be talked about. 
If you enjoy #Memoirs I would highly recommend to put this one on your list. Please make sure to check all the #TriggerWarnings .

Some days are harder than others. Itâ€™s not that we donâ€™t want to forget, itâ€™s that our bodies literally donâ€™t let us. Trust me, if I could forget, I would. 
â–â–â–â–â–â–â–â–â–â–â–â–â–â–
The last week has been particularly hard, draining. A lot of memories are bogging down my mind, even in my dreams.

The only thing I can do for myself is follow through with the healthy ways I learned to cope.

Anna tells her story of teen dating violence when, as a freshman, she was â€œinstantly hookedâ€ by a varsity athlete who made her feel greatâ€”until he didnâ€™t. Read Annaâ€™s story via our highlights or linktree. 

Looking back on her traumatic experience, Anna @feelinghealingenhanced wants others to recognize the warning signs of teen dating and how to get help. She recommends the @sashclubs â€œTeen Dating Violenceâ€ Power Topic presentation, via our Power Topics highlight or linktree. 

Anna, like many survivors of abuse by male athletes, found it pointless to report because the school ignored victims. If Annaâ€™s school had taken the proper steps to support reporting students, she could have avoided years of trauma. Schools must create a safe environment for all students, take reports compassionately, and act quickly to stop the harassment. 

Check out SASH Club's Additional Activities page to improve the climate at school or visit @ssaisorg.

@tylerperry story deeply resonates with me. His candid interview with @oprah in 2010 marked a pivotal moment in my own journey of healing and self-discovery. Perryâ€™s words echoed in my mind, unlocking a profound understanding of my own past. In that moment, his voice became my voice, offering a glimmer of hope in the midst of my darkest struggles. His courage inspires us to confront our own shadows, embrace vulnerability, and stand in solidarity with survivors. Perryâ€™s story is not just one of survival; it is a testament to the resilience of the human spirit and the enduring power of hope. I have never crossed paths with Tyler Perry, yet his impact on my life is profound. He was the beacon of hope that illuminated my path, for which I will always be grateful.

Tomorrow night we open FORCE, a new one-woman-play by @dan_brown_rockaway_ . My friend @_amandaferguson came to see a rehearsal last week, and when we were discussing the run afterwords she said: â€œthis story is so important being told through a singular, female voice.â€ I canâ€™t stop thinking about her words. This play is about a random act of sexual assault and the choices Sarabeth makes in the wake of her healing. So often when these stories are told, even though demonized, we still hear the male voice. Heâ€™s still on the stage, taking up space. We still get the other side of the story. I never thought about how powerful it is to hear this story, through one voice, one girl, one truth. When I said yes to being on stage for a whole play all by myselfâ€¦I never realized I would be saying yes to putting heart to the voices of so many women who need these stories told without the other side. Iâ€™m not alone up there afterall. I hope you come to see this play. Opening night is sold out, but we still have a few tickets left for Friday-Sunday. ğŸŸï¸ link in bio.

2b has a long history of presenting Hannah Moscovitch's new works. 'The Russian Play & Mexico City' in 2008/2010, 'East of Berlin' in 2009/2011, 'What a Young Wife Ought To Know' in 2015/17/18, and of course - 'Old Stock: A Refugee Love Story'. Which opened in 2017 and has been touring the world ever since. 

We are thrilled to be presenting Hannah's work once more, with the world premiere of her latest work, 'Red Like Fruit'. A searing interrogation of the many contradictions and complexities of complicity, consent, patriarchy and traumatic memory in the post #MeToo era.

Tickets are on sale now and selling fast - get yours before they're gone, through the link in our bio.

â­ï¸Life has an uncanny way of throwing unexpected challenges our way, pushing us to the brink of despair. Growing up in a difficult childhood, witnessing alcoholism in my family, battling depression, and experiencing the heart-wrenching loss of a cherished person have shaped the person I am today. In this post, I will share my personal journey of how these adversities have not only changed my life but also transformed my mind in a positive and empowering way.â­ï¸

Over in America, there has been increasing hateful legislation against transgender people proposed and implemented. Such legislation enables and perpetuates hate crimes, including those against children. 

Earlier this month, Nex Benedict, a 16 year old non-binary student and member of the Choctaw nation was brutally attacked in the bathroom at school by their classmates, who had been bullying them for their gender identity. The school didnâ€™t call an ambulance or report the incident to police, and suspended Nex. They died the next day.

Trans people around the world face dangerous transphobia. They face high rates of abuse and assault, and higher barriers to support. This is not just an American problem; it is also the case here in Australia. 

Children deserve safety. Trans people deserve safety. 

Rest in peace, Nex ğŸ©·ğŸ¤ğŸ©µ

Only my third book for 2024, as she has been in a reading SLUMP. 5/5â­ï¸

I have been putting off this read, because I was scared to see myself in its pages. Sometimes it is shamefully easier to close your ears and hearts to survivors and their stories, because to sit with them in their pain can be challenging. I had to take breaks during this, but I am glad I read it. Beautifully written, incredibly strong and sad, and angry, and hopeful.

â€œ How much was I expected to take, to absorb and ignore, while they yelled and clicked their tongues, so freely, with no fear of being confronted. Was I stubborn for wanting to walk, was I asking too much?â€

Nothing pisses us off more than when people say that sexual assault is not an issue, or itâ€™s not that bad, or it doesnâ€™t happen that often. So many social justice issues are shrouded in ignorance by communities. Many people do not take the time to understand the true issues society faces when it comes to sexual violence and the horrible impacts that face survivors. We need to continue to fight for what is right and fight for education so people start taking this more seriously. #sexualassault #sexualassaultawareness #survivors #fightforwhatsright #education #metoo

Join us for a conversation about the weaponization of #defamation lawsuits against survivors of sexual violence. 

PANELISTS:Â 
ğŸ”¸ï¸ Dr. Mandi GrayÂ (Trent University), assistant professor & anti-violence activist.Â Author of "Suing for Silence: Sexual Violence and Defamation".

ğŸ”¸ï¸Anju Fujioka, sexual assault lawyer & LISA supervising lawyer.

Moderated by ChanÃ¨le Rioux-McCormick, lawyer, McKenzie Lake & LISA co-founder

ğŸŸ FREE ADMISSION. RSVP to the event for your chance to win a free signed copy of the book! LINK IN BIO

ğŸ• Light refreshments served.

ABOUT THE BOOK: The arrival of the #MeToo movement was long overdue, putting sexual violence in the spotlight and opening up public discussion of the problem. It also sparked a global anti-feminist backlash. In Suing for Silence, Mandi Gray critically examines how abusive men use defamation lawsuits as a weapon against anyone who attempts to hold them accountable. 

There will be an opportunity for audience Q&A and a meet and greet with the author.

We will be accepting cash donations at the event to help support LISA.

We confront the unfortunate  reality that for every 15 Black women who endure the trauma of rape, only 1 feels empowered to report her assault. 

This disparity underscores the systemic barriers and pervasive stigma that hinder survivors from seeking justice and support. Itâ€™s a reminder of the urgent need to dismantle structures of oppression and cultivate a culture of belief, support, and empowerment for all survivors. 

We stand with those silenced by fear and systemic injustice, committed to amplifying their voices and advocating for systemic change. Together, we strive for a world where every survivor feels safe, heard, and valued ğŸ’™

I will get them back & we will be compensated for these years of torture & pain. This never should have happened. 

There is a war at home. If only someone knew?

The #MeToo movement has put sexual harassment in the spotlight, but it is definitely not a new occurrence.

In a nationwide study conducted by the UC San Diego Center on Gender Equity and Health, 81% of women reported experiencing some form of sexual harassment and/or assault in their lifetime. 38% of these women reported the offenses happening in their workplace or school.

Being the victim of sexual harassment in the workplace can have a devastating impact mentally and emotionally on a person. No one should have to face the burdens of workplace harassment alone.

If you feel you have been harassed or mistreated in the workplace, call me today to set up a case evaluation at 423-406-1151.

Relationships aren't set in stone, they can shift and evolve over time. While healthy relationships can bring us closer, unhealthy ones may start to exhibit concerning behaviours such as threats, control, or even physical aggression. 

These signs can sometimes be subtle, masked by the initial excitement of a new connection. Here are some signs of a healthy relationship and red flags that indicate potential issues. 

Remember, while relationships naturally evolve, they should never compromise your safety or independence. Healthy relationships are built on respect, open communication, and mutual understanding.

Le molestie online si fanno sempre piÃ¹ sofisticate e pericolose, soprattutto per i giovanissimi. Secondo un sondaggio, il 59% degli adolescenti statunitensi ha avuto almeno unâ€™esperienza diretta di molestie online.
Nel corso del tempo, le piattaforme hanno promesso interventi piÃ¹ o meno risolutori, che perÃ² si sono rivelati inefficaci.
Si Ã¨ parlato di verificare lâ€™etÃ  dellâ€™utente tramite carta di credito o documento dâ€™identitÃ , o con il riconoscimento facciale; ma un bambino puÃ² usare le carte di credito o dâ€™identitÃ  che trova in casa, e i sistemi di riconoscimento facciale potrebbero non calcolare bene lâ€™etÃ .
Anche i meccanismi di parental control sono facili da aggirare: su Instagram per esempio molti minori hanno aperto account business per evitare la verifica dellâ€™etÃ . 
Peccato che quel tipo di profilo sia di default visibile a tutta la comunitÃ  online. 
E le minacce non sono solo nei social. 
EpicGames, casa produttrice del famosissimo videogioco Fortnite, Ã¨ stata multata per aver raccolto i dati dei videogiocatori minorenni e averli indotti a fare acquisti in Rete senza verificare che ci fosse la supervisione di un genitore.
Una cosa Ã¨ certa: i minori continuano a vedere contenuti inappropriati e a subire molestie e tentativi di adescamento, quindi le misure adottate dalle piattaforme sono piÃ¹ una facciata che un meccanismo di protezione funzionante.
Fintanto che non si avrÃ  la piena â€“ e reale â€“ collaborazione da parte delle Big Tech, le norme rischiano di rimanere inapplicate.

Book 5 of 2024: Last year I read (and loved) â€œThe Husbandsâ€ by Chandler Baker, and after that I added this book to my TBR. This book is â€œBig Little Liesâ€ plus the #MeToo movement. A group of women in an office with their secrets, a spreadsheet of sexual offenders, mothers working full-time jobs and raising kids. The last element was common from The Husbands and I am a fan of how Chandler Baker describes the experience in such a universal language. 
I am not too fond of non-linear storytelling generally, and this book relies on that a lot to keep the secrecy about certain events. Blame it on my worldliness or the predictability of the story, I was able to figure out the â€œsecretsâ€ before these unraveled on the pages. This is not to say that I did not enjoy the book. 
The story seemed very regular to me, but it deserves telling because I am sure this is only a womanâ€™s experience. There are still people (read: men AND women) who refuse to believe women when they are sexually harassed. In fact, this book shows the mental dilemma of one of the central characters when one of her work friends expects her support against a senior, while she is debating why she was never harassed at work. 
The book has universal truth bombs about harassment at work across departments, socio-economic strata, and industries. The female friendships, seemingly unconditional, are not all rosy in this book. These are real, imperfect women with betrayals, jealousies, and other myriad human emotions towards other women. 
Overall, an entertaining book which kept me invested in the imperfect characters and their pursuits.

CW: Sexual abuse, harassment, coercion, retaliation

A recent lawsuit has been filed against Disney by an employee, identified as Jane Doe, after the company concealed sexual misconduct by former executive Nolan Gonzales, and retaliated against her with a demotion.

She revealed that management repeatedly ignored complaints about Gonzales, allowing him to harass women without consequences due to his revenue-generating role. The lawsuit states that Gonzales assaulted Jane Doe multiple times in 2017 using drugs and coercion, with threats to release intimate videos if she resisted. 

Despite previous complaints, Gonzales reportedly stepped down in 2022 only after additional harassment reports surfaced. 

This lawsuit emphasizes the critical need for large corporations and studios to prioritize employee protection, and the importance of implementing robust policies to address complaints promptly and impartially. Today, and always, we stand with Jane Doe, survivors of Nolan Gonzales, and with all survivors and Silence Breakers.

#HireSurvivors #Hollywood #HireSurvivorsHollywood #Survivors #MeToo #MeTooMovement

Today I was the bravest iâ€™ve been in a long time ğŸ¤

Today I told my mam about what happened to me as a child, as a teenager and as a young adult at the hands of different perpetrators 

My brain told me she was going to respond with blame, shame, anger and disappointment. It turned out that I was actually just projecting those emotions onto her because thats how I sometimes feel within myself ğŸ¤

She responded with love, acceptance and said she was proud of me ğŸ¥º she told me I was brave, that she understood and that none of those events were my fault. She told me she was glad I told her if it meant part of my healing. She said she was happy I told her and gave me a big cuddle. She told me she believed me

I feel like this is one of the biggest steps iâ€™ve taken yet and after 17 years of continuous silence, iâ€™ve finally been able to come clean ğŸ¤

We talked then about my mental health through the years that she lived through with me. My anorexia diagnosis as a teen, the two years of self harm and suicidal tendencies that came in my late teens and my most recent CPTSD diagnosis. She told me she loved me and that sheâ€™s proud of how far I have come despite the trauma ğŸ¤

The validation iâ€™ve wanted for so long, but been so scared to seek outğŸ¤ so glad I was brave today ğŸ¤

So pleased to share that I've recently been approved as an Approved Counsellor for victims of crime under the Victims Services Approved Counselling Service (ACS) in NSW. 

This scheme gives approved clients up to 22 hours of free sessions for counselling related to the psychological injuries sustained as a result of their experience of crime. 

My specialties relate to victims and survivors of:
adult survivors of child seggsual abuse
recent seggsual assault 
young people (16-21) 
members of the LGBTIQ+ community 

To see if you're eligible for the scheme head to: https://victimsservices.justice.nsw.gov.au/victims-services/how-can-we-help-you/victims-support-scheme/eligibility-criteria.html

To find my profile link under the scheme head to: https://victimsservices.justice.nsw.gov.au/victims-services/how-can-we-help-you/victims-support-scheme/counselling.html#Find4 

Delighted that I'm now able to offer access to this kind of support with less financial barriers.

An Instagram post by an 18-year-old girl from Prayagraj has now led to a trial court in the city awarding 20 years jail term to a man above 60 years of age. 

Uploaded in April 2019 â€” in the aftermath of a MeToo movement that had gripped the country â€” her post was a detailed account of her sexual abuse by her private tutor, Sunil Dua, over a few months between October 2013 and February 2014. She was in class 7 then and was 13 years old.

It was her post that alerted her parents to what she had gone through. 

Talking to ThePrint, her father now recalls that as soon as he read her post, they decided to file a complaint against Dua. 

â€œWe did not allow any time to lapse after her post. There was no time spent in any discussions,â€ he said. The FIR was filed on 14 April 2019, and thus, the trial began.

During the hearing, the father also read out a statement to the court. â€œIf a paedophile is hidden, he can damage so many lives. I told the judge that a paedophile is like a serial killer. He (Dua) was a loner, never got married and he never revealed his address,â€ he told ThePrint.

Read more at link in bio/IG story

// Sexual Harassment Awareness Seminar //
Stand Up
Speak Out 
Stop Harrassment
The seminar organized by AICHE UET Lahore New Campus has concluded successfully! Held on *February 14, 2024* from 11 am to 12:30 pm in the ESD Lab, Chemical Engineering Department, the session featured *Dr. Hilal Fatima* , Chairperson of Communication (Mass Leads University), shedding light on critical issues like sexual harassment awareness, workplace ethics, and HEC policies on women's harassment. 
Thank you to all who attended and contributed to the meaningful dialogue and education.

Future; this is to you.Â 

How can flowers blossom
tress can grow
water can flow freely, without my curious mind?

How can the sun shine so bright,
how can I ever look at nature wondering,Â 
where do I fit in this narrative?

Yet, why is the ego in conflict with its own home?
Why do we decide to deny,Â 
when all I we have every done is taken
the fruit from nature,
without ever wondering why should I?

Somewhere down the line,
I know we will find a way to rejoiceâ€”Â 
just as it was intended was our first glimpse with you
but until then,
there are still many rivers to cross
and too many lessons to be learned

DESCRIPTION:
Anna tells her story of teen dating violence when, as a freshman, she was â€œinstantly hookedâ€ by a varsity athlete who made her feel greatâ€”until he didnâ€™t. Read Annaâ€™s story via our highlights or linktree. 

Looking back on her traumatic experience, Anna wants others to recognize the warning signs of teen dating and how to get help. She recommends the @sashclubs â€œTeen Dating Violenceâ€ Power Topic presentation, via our Power Topics highlight or linktree. 

Anna @feelinghealingenhanced, like many survivors of abuse by male athletes, found it pointless to report because the school ignored victims. If Annaâ€™s school had taken the proper steps to support reporting students, she could have avoided years of trauma. Schools must create a safe environment for all students, take reports compassionately, and act quickly to stop the harassment. Too often schools donâ€™t--so students are denied their right to an education free from sexual harassment as guaranteed by Title IX, a federal civil rights law. 

Use @ssaisorg toolkits (in our highlights) to ensure your school is taking the required steps to protect students.

Have an interest in learning about the intersectionality of disabilities and sexualized violence? We have just the resource for you! 

Join us on your lunch break for our free webinar, "Disability & Sexualized Violence:
Exploring the Intersection" on Wednesday, March 12th, 2024 at 12pm - 1pm. If you can't make it on the day, still be sure to register and you will receive a recording of the webinar afterwards. 

Disability & Sexualized Violence:
People living with disabilities, both mental and physical, self-report having experienced sexualized violence at alarming rates. The exact numbers are difficult to determine, as this intersection is often not studied or researched. Educating those living with disabilities about consent and violence is equally (if not more?) important, as well as the folks that support them. Learn more about this particular intersection, and strategies for educating youth and young adults about consent and violence, in this lunch-n-learn webinar.

I Like to Watch by Emily Nussbaum. This collection of Pulitzer Prizeâ€“winning Nussbaumâ€™s favourite columns sheâ€™s written over the years is every TV loverâ€™s dream. Beginning with how Buffy the Vampire Slayer turned her into a TV critic and then running through columns about The Sopranos, Girls, Adventure Time, Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt, LOST, Hannibal, black-ish, and soooo many more, itâ€™s a romp through the last 20 or so years of television. Occasionally youâ€™ll reach a story where thereâ€™s a wee bit of a cringe factor due to stories that wouldnâ€™t come out until laterâ€”Joss Whedon is still a geek god, for instanceâ€”and despite the actual book being published after most of those stories had broken, I appreciated her just leaving them within the context of their own time. Nussbaum has always been a brilliant TV critic, and itâ€™s rather refreshing to go back to a time thatâ€™s, well, not now. Sometimes sheâ€™ll drop little things into the middle of an interview that had me laughing out loudâ€”my absolute favourite was the blink-and-youâ€™d-miss-it nugget that Jenji Kohan, the creator of Orange Is the New Black and GLOW, has a pitbull named Gail Feldmanâ€¦ which made my husband and I LOL and decide weâ€™re naming our future cats Morty Sherman, Devorah Goldberg, and Judy Feinstein. But the heart of this book is a remarkable essay that lands smack in the middle of it, one that she wrote specifically for the book, called â€œConfessions of the Human Shield.â€ In it she addresses the very thing I mentioned above: that sometimes people do bad things, and the wrong peopleâ€”often fans or TV criticsâ€”get caught in the crossfire for ever having liked them in the first place, something all of us have felt as fans at one point or another, especially in the past 20 years. This 50-page essay addresses specifically the #MeToo movement and Harvey Weinstein accusations, and how the two caused a tsunami that would spiral through what she did for a livingâ€”in all the best and worst ways. Itâ€™s jaw-droppingly good, and if you only read one part of this book, make it that essay. But I hope you read the entire book, which is an amazing look back at the TV shows we love, and why. #bookstagram

DESCRIPTION:
"This intersection of women, violence, and purity has resulted in more than victim blaming and the idolization of predators like GGW - the purity myth is significantly changing the cultural and political landscape as it relates to violence and women. Women have always been blamed for sexual violence done to them; that's nothing new. But in an allegedly post-feminist world, where rape and domestic violence are supposed to be universally reviled, arguments that overtly (or stealthily) blame women, or dismiss violence against them, have that much more power. Because who in this day and age would say that rape is a good thing? Or that a woman just got what was coming to her? No one; instead, today's rape apologism comes wrapped in the rhetoric of equality - That's what makes it different, and so dangerous.

In a 2008 Los Angeles Times article, for example, reporter Heather Mac Donald wrote that there simply is no rape problem on college campuses. In response to a Harvard woman's story about being raped while she was drunk, Mac Donald's wrote that to hold her 'without responsibility requires stripping women of volition and moral agency.'...

This insidious argument about 'responsibility' is having an acute effect on the way all women talk about rape. The very notion of what rape is is being debated - and not in a progressive or useful way....

Of course, many women don't call their assaults rape, for myriad reasons - perhaps because of the shame and stigma attached to sexual assault, or maybe they shy away from the word because they don't want to admit something so awful happen to them. But whatever the reason, it doesn't change the reality of what happened - It doesn't change the fact that someone raped them.

As dangerous as Sessions Stepp's claim that there is such a thing as 'gray rape' is her insinuation that some women are too empowered to be victims...Claims like these, and playing with language without regard for women's experiences, have real life consequences."

Author @jessicavalenti
From #thepuritymyth
Artist Red K.Elders @rkelders.art

Teen dating violence takes many forms including psychological aggression: verbal or non-verbal communication to emotionally harm or control another person. It can also include repeated, unwanted attention or contact (like intrusively checking emails and texts) that causes fear or concern for oneâ€™s own safety. The many warning signs are included in our @sashclubs Teen Dating Violence Power Topic (via highlights). It offers a fast-moving video â€œDating Abuse: Toolkit for Talking to Teensâ€ with scenarios for people of all genders created by @jewishwomenintl. Thanks for collaborating, CEO 
@meredith_jacobs.

"A true-life story - a young girl with hopes and dreams left the local city for the bright lights of London - with highs and lows. A true reader rollercoaster! Vickiâ€™s life story - warts and all is an incredible journey. It has made me question stereotypes whilst experiencing the extreme euphoria along with the downright low points of life in this incredible laid bare book.â€ - Jo 
 
Like so many others, I wanted to escape my reality. How many of us are doing this even today. 
 
The truth of â€œthe Naked Truthâ€ is that I could never escape it until I allowed myself to accept it. 

Sign up to the waitlist to access a powerful story of hope and healing. I hope it not only inspires you, but also brings you laughter and acknowledgement along the way.

Gli incontri saranno presso la Sala Consiliare al Castello dei Da Peraga del Comune di Vigonza, ore 20,30
- mercoledÃ¬ 28 febbraio: Artiste visuali, dagli albori alle soglie del'900
- giovedÃ¬ 28 marzo: Artiste visuale del '900 e primi 2000 
- mercoledÃ¬ 24 aprile: Architette e Designers

-Incontri promossi dal Centro Veneto progetti Donna di Padova, Comune di Vigonza, in collaborazione con l'associazione Lottodiognimese 

Tonight the first of the 4 lectures for images and words that I'll hold on "WOMEN ARTISTS, despite everything"
My personal research on valiant women who still don't have their rightful place in history,
a list of official omissions, of unjustified forgetfulness, of fake attributions.
Naming means making one exist, recognizing means giving dignity and a correct vision of the progress of the world. Erasing from history is violence, there is no culture if there is no memory."

The lectures will be in the Council Hall at the Da Peraga Castle of Municipality of Vigonza, 8.30 pm
- Wednesday 28 February: Visual artists, from the beginning to the threshold of the 20th century
- Thursday 28 March: Visual artists of the 20th and early 2000s
- Wednesday 24 April: Architects and Designers
- Thursday 23 May: Photographers and Filmmakers
Lectures promoted by Veneto Women's Projects Center of Padua, Municipality of Vigonza, in collaboration with the Lottodiognimese association.

We excited to partner with Renee Jones Empowerment Center (@rjecempower) for Project Red Cord Night! Mark your calendars for the upcoming Project Red Cord Night Outs: March 8, April 12, April 26, May 17, June 21, July 26, & August 10. 

Renee Jones Empowerment Center (RJEC) is dedicated to offering life coaching and aftercare assistance to individuals having the fortitude to end the cycle of human trafficking in Northeast Ohio. Through cutting-edge trauma-informed programs and services, RJEC sheds light on the shadow side of humanity and offers a hopeful way to put lives back on a positive track. For more information, you can call them at (216) 417-0823.

7 years ago I was on stage at the Oscars with Lady Gaga and activists and survivors from all of the country! Lady Gaga was nominated for an Oscar for her song that was featured on The Hunting Ground, a powerful documentary about campus sexual violence. 

I am so grateful I got to have this experience. I am so grateful I got to connect with so many fellow survivors of sexual violence. I have made so many lasting friendships from this group and now know so many advocates within this space. I now know so many resources that I wish I had access to as a young survivorâ€”but I am also in the position where I have been able to help allot of people through a similar situation. 

If youâ€™re struggling with the aftermath of sexual violence or harassment, please feel free to reach out to me. I will be happy to connect you with some of the great advocates I know. I believe you. There is a way through. â¤ï¸

Also, that amazing tattoo was designed by my incredible friend @jacquelinetlin 
Jackie is one of the most incredibly talented people I have ever met! Her tattoo design, the fire rose unity survivor symbol, has become an icon for survivors all over the world. 
#metoo #metoomovement

#Consent is an important and ongoing conversation. As we learn more and continue to grow the types of conversations we have, it's clear that not everyone really has a clear understanding of what consent really is and how to apply it to everyday conversations. Sometimes it's really easy to talk about the idea as an abstract because we can lay out the black and white definitions. Most people can't make the transition to how it should actually apply in real world situations. It's easy for people to get confused and they have a lot of questions. The problem is that a lot of people still aren't seeking the answers. Some of the largest feedback that I've gotten since putting out my book February 1st is that it's making people look at consent in an entirely new way. They are considering things that they never thought about before. It's important we continue to push the boundaries of our thinking and engage in meaningful conversations about consent. Get your own copy and join the conversation. Together we can take the steps to building a consent culture! It's clear that what we've been doing so far isn't working, we need to try something different. Don't wait to start!
___________________________________________________
Pick up your copy
https://www.exploresextalk.com/product/got-consent/?utm_source=instagram

Ok, now for the full captionâ€¦ itâ€™s longâ€¦ you have been warned ğŸ˜‰â€¨â€¨As International Womenâ€™s Day approaches and I think about the many incredible women in my lifeâ€”who in spite of their own difficulties, still make space to comfort, encourage, and challenge me on a daily basisâ€”it would be crazy not to pause to celebrate them.â€¨
Looking back, the past year or so feels like it could contain a decadeâ€™s worth of hardships. So many heart-wrenching losses itâ€™s hard to keep track of them allâ€”losing my employment and financial stability to a layoff, my relationship and business partner to a breakup, my reproductive rights and healthcare access to a broken system of governing, my physical autonomy to an industry peer I trusted, and worst of allâ€”losing my ride-or-die companion and best friend of 12-years to cancer. I didnâ€™t think I would survive.â€¨â€¨But throughout it all, I was never alone. My sisterhood (by blood and by bond) came through like a force of nature, providing the resilience and strength I needed to navigate my darkest days. They were right there beside me, from carrying me through the losses, to celebrating the triumphs with me as I played my first festival and international gigs, released my first EP, and launched my own party seriesâ€”their unwavering presence and love were my support system every step of the way. â€¨
As 2024 unfolds, I feel at ease knowing that the foundation of my journey is woven with threads of resilience and perseverance by the strong women who came before me and will carry on after me. Hereâ€™s to the women who inspire and empower me every day. â€¨
 #InternationalWomensDay #reproductiverights #handsoffourbodies #genderequality #metoo

Tarana Burke, @taranajaneen, founder of the #MeTooMovement, is an African American civil rights activist known for her work in advocating for survivors of sexual violence, particularly within marginalized communities, including women of color, LGBTQ+ individuals, and low-income individuals.

Burke first coined the phrase "Me Too" in 2006 as a way to empower and support survivors of sexual assault, particularly young women of color. Her intention was to create a sense of solidarity and understanding among survivors.

She is the author of Unbound: My Story of Liberation and the Birth of the Me Too Movement, and You Are Your Best Thing: Vulnerability, Shame Resilience, and the Black Experience. Her letter to her great grandmother is included in the book, Black Love Letters, a collection of essays on community, joy, resilience and more.

DESCRIPTION:
My story - Part 1 ğŸ™ğŸ’—ğŸ’ª

If I'm honest I don't know where to begin, I've been in the the dark for a while facing and healing my past .

I was sexually abused as a child and came from an abusive family.
I was neglected , abandoned and I have pretty much been on my own my whole life.
I left home at 16 and left the UK at 17 .

I ran away from my past and have hidden this from the world and even myself. 
I had not gone through the pain, grief and anger to heal.

Therefore keeping everything inside I created a false self a people pleaser.

A people pleaser to keep the peace, to be loved and liked. To pretend everything was ok to people so that I would be accepted.

When I did have the courage to tell people my story it was too much I was a "Victim" and even told I was too dramatic , sensitive or that I thought the world was against me.

I understand that it's not easy for people to hear these things and it makes them uncomfortable , this is not really something we talk about in our society!!
They don't do it with a bad intention, they are not therapists and also when they are avoident how can they have empathy and feel for you if they don't themselves. 
I also get this as I did it my self too I've always been sensitive and have felt the sadness but I never really acknowledged what really happened I did my best not to get in a hole.

Not acknowledgeing the pain,  anger and grief I had inside I just continued surviving creating coping mechanisms to keep going and of course at one point it all came too much for me so I had to go deep inside.

Once I stopped having an eating disorder, stopped drinking and smoking and getting rid of all my distractions I started to heal.

Yoga has been a big anchor for for me.
A tool to ground and accept the process and to connect spiritually.

But it wasn't until COVID and that my daughter came in my life that I was ready to face the sexual abuse.

Are you looking to boost your cause on social media? Share your passion by telling your story! How about the story that inspired your passion? From the days of sitting around a crackling fire and telling your family and friends stories that turned into legends, time has proven that the best way to connect with people is through telling them a story.

In this short-attention-span era it's important to capture your audience's attention immediately or they will move on. I know I do! The best way to do this is with visuals to capture attention - videos/reels are an excellent method to use. Try keeping it fresh with a variety of different types of posts to keep people interested and provide them with something they want to keep coming back to see. 

And did you know this year is all about being REAL? Be real, talk to your audience, interact with your supporters, ask questions, and build a community! When people feel involved and you share your raw passion, it is much easier to ignite a fire. ğŸ”¥

Need help coming up with a strategy? Need someone to create some posts for you? Need a logo for your cause? Just slide into my DMs and let's connect!

Like, share, and comment if you found this helpful! âœŒ

Because I have PTSD also, I feel my regulated window resembles more of a delicate thin green line, ğŸ«  with hyperarousal and hypoarousal being where I tend to jump back and forth from when triggered. Found out today that the podcast I was interviewed for last year is finally being released! The first episode of "The Secret History of Antarctica: Death on the Ice," entitled "Arrival," can be found on @apple podcasts and @spotify today. 

I share my story of sexual assault in McMurdo Station in the fourth episode, "Madhouse at the End of the Earth." You can either listen to it for free when it is released on Monday, March 18th, or you can tune in to all of the episodes when you subscribe to Crowd Stories on Apple Podcasts. 

Many thanks to @crowdnetwork @annaestaufenberg (and @theeditorspeaks on X) for giving me the opportunity to spread awareness for survivors.

Posted @withregram â€¢ @crowdnetwork The Secret History is back with The Secret History of Antarctica!

Following the success of the #1 true crime seriesÂ The Secret History of Flight 149Â (2023 ARIA Nominated for Best Factual Series) andÂ The Secret History of the Estonia, journalist stephen davis is investigating an unexplained death that occurred in one of the most isolated and deadly locations in the world.

In the year 2000 a young Australian astrophysicist named Rodney Marks died in strange circumstances while conducting scientific research on Antarctica. Despite numerous inquests over the years, his tragic death remains unsolved to this day.

As the series unfolds, we learn startling details about the reality of life on the ice; a demanding, isolated existence which, as we discover, can drive people to do bad things. Stephen interrogates who was responsible for the failed investigation, and what â€“ if anything â€“ has changed in the years since the tragedy.

The Secret History of Antarctica: Death on the Ice is out now, wherever you get your podcasts.

I havenâ€™t been able to sleep since I got to Houston, my new job & certain dynamics about this have my PTSD flaring up. 

Iâ€™ve been going hard on sleeping meds but theyâ€™re not helping much. I keep crying, Iâ€™m happy & so grateful & blessed to be here & to be  starting this new job soon, but flashbacks & nightmares & just being plain scared of a monster & his unpredictable rage & past history of extreme violence due to coming to Houston during my divorce are hitting me harder than I thought. 

My ex gets really really mad when I used to go to Houston & he takes it out on my kids. He â€œbroke the babyâ€™s faceâ€ when I went camping in Houston. I thought he was gunna kill me, kill the kids just I when he used to punish me for camping in Houston. 

I havenâ€™t announced yet where Iâ€™ll be working, but he knows for who & where. That scares me & itâ€™s ok to feel things & trust myself. Iâ€™m here to get my kids back & start facing my fears. 

Self care is where Iâ€™ll be focusing. More reading. Better eating & Iâ€™m gunna try to start 5am runs again to help with this PTSD. My trauma therapist said heâ€™s only seen my level of PTSD in 3% of his patients. Thatâ€™s ok. Gunna stay sweet & happy & hardworking anyways. 

There is a war at home & my children & I are trapped in these trenches. 

There is a war at home. If only someone knew?

It is not your fault!!
You're not over sensitive!!
You haven't done anything wrong!!

Narcissists demonstrate a profound lack of empathy, unable to genuinely understand or validate the emotions and experiences of others. 

They view individuals as mere instruments for their gratification, treating them as objects to be used and discarded at will. 

This callous disregard for the feelings and needs of others is a fundamental aspect of their personality, deeply ingrained and resistant to change. 

It is so important for you to recognise that the narcissist's behaviour is not your fault; it stems from the narcissist's inherent traits and dysfunctional coping mechanisms.

In honor of #TeenDatingViolenceAwarenessMonth weâ€™re answering real questions from real teens who have attended PAVE/Survivors.org presentations.

Todayâ€™s question ğŸ’­
What should if I donâ€™t feel comfortable sharing sexual experiences with friends that want to know everything?

Youâ€™re never obligated to discuss your sexual activity with anyone. It can be difficult when friends of ours want to know our sexual history and we are uncomfortable sharing that information with them. Remember that consent isnâ€™t just for sexual activity, we should practice and respect consent in any and all contexts, including when having personal conversations with friends.

My aunt lived in that area, and we were taken there daily. I can remember her telling me I was special and that I would be a star someday. That I had to do everything she said. Listen, practice.
My father was supposed to be watching my sister and me, but he would take us there and leave us with her. For part of that time we stayed with my aunt until we could get our own place. My father was supposed to be looking for work, but he would take off with my blood uncles every day, so it got to be that I never saw either parent for long periods of time. That would change on occasion when my father would take me with him to bars while he drank or played in a band or both. I would be at the bar with one of his girlfriends. It seemed perfectly natural to me.
My aunt began to sexually abuse me the first night. It continued the entire time we were there. Months. I didn't know until years later that my sister was locked in a closet while this went on.
Eventually we got a place of our own and the abuse stopped.
A few months later my cousins came to live with us and the sexual abuse started again. Just different people. It ended a few months later when they were caught. They had us tied up. The cords were tight. Not really cords at all, cloths line. My sister and I were tied back to back. My cousins, a sister and brother had already molested us for over an hour. I cannot recall where my mother was during that period of my life. She was gone a lot. I think she was working because he didn't work. That's all I know.
