The UN has stated that they have â€œcredibleâ€ reports of sexual violence being committed against Palestinian women and girls by the IDF. Women have reported being stripped and humiliated, subjected to image based abuse, sexual assault, and rape, as well as being threatened with these violations. There is no way to frame this as self defence. 

Just as the UNâ€™s Special Representative on Sexual Violence in Conflict called for an investigation into sexual violence on the 7th of October, the UN is now calling for investigations into these crimes. Sexual violence against anyone is not ok, and sexual violence against one group does NOT justify sexual violence against another group. 

If as a survivor you are struggling because of hearing such news, please remember there is help available, including many support services pinned on our page ğŸ’–

To the young actors out there, protect yourself. Even if you feel attraction to an adult director above the age of 30â€¦ ask yourself why you are and if it seems appropriate or inappropriate for them to be secretly dating you. Ask yourself why itâ€™s a secret, and who it benefits.

DESCRIPTION:
Helpful reminder for a Monday. 

You are not your work. 

You are not the you who is late for work, early for work, enjoys your work, or can't wait for work to end. 

You are not what you do, or how you feel. 

What makes up you is a complex beautiful tapestry of experiences, dreams, potential, loves, beliefs, past lives, future lives, friendships, acquaintances, the interaction with the stranger on the train. 

Big milestones, small fancies. 

But the main message here - you are not your work. 

And therefore, do not fear a Monday morning. 

It is just another day, another opportunity to get to know yourself a little bit deeper. 

And, breathe....

DESCRIPTION:
Generous donations from our community have enabled us to renovate another room at our shelter. We very much appreciate your support.

Support of these efforts is both an investment in the only certified emergency shelter for survivors of domestic and sexual abuse in St. Johns County and their minor children and a commitment to help those transition from domestic violence victims to survivors.

Our rooms need renovations and makeovers, and we've asked for makeovers to include paint, bedding, dÃ©cor, and bathroom supplies. Last year, 325 adults and children spent 28,652 bed nights in our shelter.

Donations to this project will help with the bedroom makeovers and the needed flooring, repairs, hardware, and appliances to create a safe and welcoming environment throughout our shelter. 

With the growth we've seen in St. Johns County, more families need our help than ever before - and the complexity of those needs has also increased. 

If you'd like to help, please call our office at (904) 808-8544 or donate any amount online at the link in our profile, and write room makeover in the comments. 

If you're being abused or have been abused, please call the Betty Griffin Center 24-hour crisis hotline at (904) 824-1555, or TTY users dial (904) 827-0236. Text us at https://bettygriffincenter.org/ by clicking on the blue icon.

DESCRIPTION:
ğŸš¨NEW EPISODEğŸš¨

Chloe Wade on Writing for Theatre and her new play As SHE Likes It

Chloe is an actor, writer and theatre maker who trained at the International School of Acting and Central School of Speech and Drama. 

With over 10 years of working in film, TV and theatre she is best known for playing Joanne Grantham in BBCâ€™s Doctors and the lead role in independent film Honeycomb Lodge that won the Best Film at the Delhi International Film Festival. Over lockdown she starred alongside Helen Mirren in The Secret Life of Ophelia. 

She is also the alumna of the Actor-Writer course and is a supported writer of the Sheffield Theatreâ€™s Bank Cohort. Chloe is currently reigning champion of the Birmingham Repâ€™s Monologue Slam competition with her piece â€œMay I Take Your Order Pleaseâ€, based on her time working in hospitality. 

In this episode we discuss Chloeâ€™s brand new play thatâ€™s currently on tour across the UK, As SHE Likes It, a play bringing to light the sexual harassment that has/is going on in Hollywood and how it dates back back to the 1920s, not just to Harvey Weinstein. 

The play is based on the story of actress Patricia Douglas who was abused at an MGM party in 1937. Despite her efforts to bring her perpetrators to justice the case was thrown out and nothing came of it. I had the privilege to see and review the show with @uppercircle_theatre (review group that Chloe and I are part of) you can find it on my profile. Itâ€™s a fantastic piece packed with harsh truths that everyone needs to hear and see to stop this harassment from continuing. 

Check out Chloeâ€™s website and Instagram for more information on her, the tour and how to get in touch. 

Website: chloe-wade.com
Instagram: @chloewadprod @yorkshirewade

This XXIst century is offering us all many societal shifts
Funny I am writing this post in February, the month of carnival which societal objective is that of roles reversal within a human group.
#metoo began with women and cascaded through many different professions.
Let's be clear, it is not a question of profession, but a societal structural one.

Any abused child who could not be witnessed and trusted in their pain remains stuck with loneliness, hurt, fear, shame â€¦within the adult who is carrying them
The gender of the child does not matter, the pain is similar.
What changes is the perception of 
what is a woman: kind, gentle, patient, smiling, sweet, weak, emotional, a mother or a whore 
and what is a man: strong, powerful, a leader, does not show emotions, solid, a knight, a warrior
well, no.
all of those traits can belong to a man or a woman
Working with an adult is working with kids and teens

Thank you @aurelien_wiik to state the reality
~~~~~~~

As Australia reels in the wake of another domestic violence related homicide, we really need to address how we talk about these issues. 

We immediately had the press sensationalising the murder, reframing and focusing on it as the outcome of a â€œlove triangleâ€, a scandal to be gossiped about rather than taken seriously. 

We then had the Police Commissioner calling it a â€œcrime of passionâ€. Murders perceived as crimes of passion get taken less seriously by courts, as well as the media (as we have already seen). It also overlooks the power dynamics involved with the alleged murder being a police officer who used a police-issued firearm as the murder weapon. Australia has long had a very serious problem with police officers failing to take action against other police officers accused of domestic violence. 

There is then also the issue of domestic violence being taken less seriously in the context of LGBT relationships. LGBT victim-survivors face far more barriers to support and justice.

We canâ€™t keep excusing, enabling, and protecting abusers. 

Luke Davies and Jesse Baird should still be alive, enjoying their lives together, enjoying the love they had for each other, enjoying the Sydney Mardi Gras with the LGBTQ community.

A few days ago, Education Ministers agreed to the Action Plan Addressing Gender-based Violence in Higher Education, which so many people have been advocating for for years. 

Thank you and congratulations to The Stop Campaign (@thestopcampaignaus), End Rape On Campus Australia (@erocaustralia), Our Watch (@ourwatch), Fair Agenda (@fair_agenda) and many more who made this possible; eg. victim-survivors, students and academics, advocates, support services, and policy makers who campaigned for these changes, journalists who brought more attention to it, donors who backed the organisations behind it, etc

Go to www.saferunis.org to learn more & use #IDeserveSafety to push this issue to the top of the national agenda!

People endure victim shaming, disbelief, and blame. . 2 men posted on a tread that Suzie Lamplu and Shirley Banks would be a alive today if I had spoke up. Laying the blame for their murders on me not the murderer! But a deeply traumatised child threatened with a return visit if I told anyone. The police and justice system does no better it often treats us as inconveniences, failing to provide adequate support when we speak up. This enables known abusers to perpetuate harm against any child they encounter. Victims are forced to prove their victimhood, bear the financial burden of therapy and treatment, and suffer from stigma and misinformation, leading to distrust of men who disclose childhood sexual abuse when around children. We are the victims not the perpetrators! Stop making out we need to prove weâ€™re innocent in our own crimes and abuse firstly before affording us an investigation. Unas manos interpretan, en lengua de signos, las palabras â€œSe acabÃ³â€; decÃ­a Spivak que los sujetos subalternos no podÃ­an hablar no por su incapacidad fÃ­sica (de la que sÃ­ disponÃ­an) sino por su estatus en el margen, sin capacidad de enunciarse o nombrarse. Spivak hablaba de ese espacio en blanco entre las palabras que, si bien no tiene sonido, tiene entidad y existe, aunque permanezca en silencio. De la misma forma, estas manos interpretan un mensaje que es global, que se hizo viral en 2017 con un #MeToo y un #TimesUp pero que sigue vigente con un #SeAcabÃ³ que es tambiÃ©n internacional. Un grito concentrado en unas manos precisas.

.

Some hands interpret, in sign language, the words "It's over"; Spivak said that subaltern subjects could not speak not because of their physical incapacity (which they did have) but because of their status on the margin, without the capacity to enunciate or name themselves. Spivak spoke of that blank space between words that, although it has no sound, has an entity and exists, even if it remains silent. In the same way, these hands interpret a message that is global, that went viral in 2017 with a #MeToo and a #TimesUp but that remains valid with a #SeAcabÃ³ that is also international. A cry concentrated in precise hands.

DESCRIPTION:
Authored By: Simran
The PoSH Act was put into effect to shield women from sexual harassment at work and to prevent it from happening, providing a safe atmosphere for them to work in. As a mandatory compliance with the PoSH Act, any organization with more than ten employees must set up an Internal Complaints Committee (ICC) in the prescribed manner to receive and handle women's complaints of sexual harassment in a highly confidential and time-bound manner. The POSH Act is not gender-neutral; only women can register complaints.
Read More: https://www.barelaw.in/prevention-of-women-from-sexual-harassment-in-the-workplace/
Visit our website at: www.barelaw.in

ğŸŒŸ Healing Sexual Trauma ğŸŒŸ

Today, I want to take a moment to shed light on a topic thatâ€™s incredibly important yet often silenced: healing from sexual trauma.

Sexual trauma can leave deep scars on our hearts and minds, impacting every aspect of our lives. 

But I want you to know that healing is possible. Itâ€™s a journey that takes time, courage, and support, but it is within reach.

If youâ€™re struggling with the aftermath of sexual trauma, please know that you are not alone. 

There are resources and communities out there ready to offer guidance, understanding, and a safe space to heal.

Remember, your experiences do not define you. 

You are resilient, worthy of love, and deserving of peace. 

Itâ€™s okay to seek help and to take care of yourself along the way.

Letâ€™s break the silence, support one another, and walk hand in hand on the path to healing.
